First Targets Are Seen For Line-Item Veto President Clinton has decided to exercise his line-item veto authority for the first time, striking out at least one narrow tax break and one spending measure from the balanced-budget and tax-cut legislation he signed last week.

Congressional officials have said the likely candidates for vetoes -- which could be overridden by Congress -- are a part of the change in the Medicaid program and a provision that would allow the deferral of taxes for the sale of a food-processing plant to farmers' cooperatives. $(Page A1.$)

Groups to Challenge Wiretap Plans Privacy advocates plan to challenge the F.B.I.'s plan for high-technology wiretapping, contending that the agency is seeking new powers never intended by Congress when it enacted a 1994 law to bring wiretapping into the digital age. $(D2.$)

Oil Use at Record Levels American drivers are consuming record quantities of gasoline this year, and the nation's dependence on imported oil is also setting records as domestic production slowly declines. $(A1.$)

Intervention Sought in Strike Officials at the United Parcel Service stepped up their calls for President Clinton to intervene to end the teamsters' strike, but Administration officials said he was leaning strongly against doing so. $(A13.$)

In Anti-Corruption Push, Results The first fruits of a new policy by the World Bank and the I.M.F. to use their leverage with poorer nations to try to stamp out corruption and promote better governance are starting to become visible. $(A4.$)

High-Technology Turnstile Jumpers The thousand or so hackers gathered at a conference in Manhattan had a new dream target: the Metrocard, and the $700 million computer system that transit officials installed to make it work. $(A1.$)

Museums' Caution About the Web The rise of the Internet has forced museum directors to grapple with an old problem in a new universe. In cyberspace, it is unclear how best to balance their twin missions of making art available to the public and protecting the value and integrity of the art. $(D5.$)
Clouds Over E.D.S.'s Future After Electronic Data Systems reported a disappointing outlook for earnings, analysts have been raising questions about the company's direction. Market Place. $(D4.$)
HarperCollins's Challenge After deep cost cuts, HarperCollins is faced with the task of convincing agents and authors that its commitment to the future is truly nonfiction. Publishing. $(D9.$)
Transformation in Music Charting In only six years, Soundscan has drastically changed the music charting system, and by extension, altered the way the recording industry does business. $(D5.$)

Yamaichi Executives to Step Down Yamaichi Securities said it would appoint a new president and chairman as part of a leadership change as authorities investigate the brokerage firm in a racketeer payoff scandal. The company said its 11 directors, including the chairman, Tsugio Yukihira, and president, Atsuo Miki, would step down. $(D2.$)

Shift on Nuclear Policy The Energy Department, its own big nuclear reactors broken down irreparably, is preparing to borrow space in a civilian power plant to manufacture tritium for nuclear weapons. The plan would break a taboo that has existed since the beginning of the atomic age: that civilian reactors are not to be put to military uses. $(A10.$)
